repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body: This PR adds the [`mt19937`](https://www.cplusplus.com/reference/random/mt19937/) random number generator to `libcpp`.

comment_data.body: This seems a reasonable value to pass as an argument into this test function.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,51 @@
+# mode: run
+# tag: cpp, cpp11
+
+from libcpp.random cimport mt19937
+
+
+def mt19937_seed_test():
+    """
+    >>> mt19937_seed_test()
+    1608637542
+    """
+    cdef mt19937 rd = mt19937(42)
+    return rd()
+
+
+def mt19937_reseed_test():
+    """
+    >>> mt19937_reseed_test()
+    1608637542
+    """
+    cdef mt19937 rd
+    rd.seed(42)
+    return rd()
+
+
+def mt19937_min_max():
+    """
+    The minimum is zero and the maximum is 2 ** 32 - 1 because mt19937 is 32 bit.
+    >>> mt19937_min_max()
+    (0, 4294967295)
+    """
+    cdef mt19937 rd
+    return rd.min(), rd.max()
+
+
+def mt19937_discard():
+    """
+    >>> mt19937_discard()
+    (1972458954, 1972458954)
+    """
+    cdef mt19937 rd = mt19937(42)
+    # Throw away z random numbers.
+    z = 13

comment_data.body: I'm not sure if this global import helps in doctests. But you're also not making use of it in any of the `print()` calls below, soâ€¦
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,12 +1,13 @@
 # mode: run
 # tag: cpp, cpp11
 
+from __future__ import print_function

comment_data.body: Ah, sorry, this line tells python2 to use python3 syntax for print, i.e. `print(some, values)` rather than `print some, values`. Admittedly, importing an object that's later unused to change the code parsing is a somewhat surprising choice. Some more details [here](https://docs.python.org/3/reference/simple_stmts.html#future).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,12 +1,13 @@
 # mode: run
 # tag: cpp, cpp11
 
+from __future__ import print_function

comment_data.body:
:-D  Thanks, but I know what future imports do. I implemented that specific one in Cython back in 2008.

I was suggesting that a) I don't think this import has an effect on doctests in strings of the same module (but I don't know for sure), and b) the print calls below work exactly the same as print statements in Py2, even without the future import. So, in any case, the future import is not needed here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,12 +1,13 @@
 # mode: run
 # tag: cpp, cpp11
 
+from __future__ import print_function

comment_data.body: Ha, I'm of course preaching to the choir, apologies. I'll drop the future import, and it looks like the tests are passing.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,12 +1,13 @@
 # mode: run
 # tag: cpp, cpp11
 
+from __future__ import print_function

comment_data.body: Ok, so, I looked up the code in [doctest](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/main/Lib/doctest.py) and it has support for reading the future imports used in the module (good to know, and certainly makes sense). However, this is a compiled Cython module, and `doctest` certainly cannot figure out the original future imports used in the source code there.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,12 +1,13 @@
 # mode: run
 # tag: cpp, cpp11
 
+from __future__ import print_function

commit.message: Add mt19937 random number generator to libcpp.
Change num. discards for mt19937 test to argument.
Use print for doctest to handle python2 and python3.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

milestone.description:
Goals:
â€“ New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
â€“ Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
â€“ Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
â€“ Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: Add mt19937 random number generator to libcpp.
